newsitem.title: USA: NASA asteroid probe views Mathilde on way to Eros.
newsitem.headline: NASA asteroid probe views Mathilde on way to Eros.

text.p: A NASA space probe waltzed by the asteroid Mathilde on Friday in a fortuitous peek at this large, dark, slow-turning rock on its way to another asteroid, Eros.

The first images made by the Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous (NEAR) satellite showed the skull-like face of Mathilde, an irregularly shaped "stealth asteroid" with a diameter of roughly 38 miles (61 km).

NEAR will get no nearer to Mathilde than 750 miles (1,200 km), but that should be close enough to glimpse features as small as a football field, according to scientists at Johns Hopkins University's Applied Physics Laboratory outside Washington, which built the space probe for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
The unmanned craft was expected to snap about 780 pictures of Mathilde's dark surface as it sped by at 22,000 mph (35,000 kpm) this weekend.
The first image, which reached Earth on Friday morning, showed a pockmarked lump that looked eerily like a human skull, complete with eye sockets and a gaping mouth.
The mouth was a crater as deep as Mount Everest is high, researchers said as the images were beamed down to Earth. A second image showed a deep gash.

Researchers know little about Mathilde except that it is extremely dark and probably loaded with carbon. Less than 4 percent of the light that hits Mathilde is reflected back, making it one of the blackest objects in our solar system, and NEAR scientist Donald Yeomans dubbed it the "stealth asteroid" because much of it remains dark.
Mathilde is currently about 205 million miles (330 million km) away from Earth in a wide band of asteroids between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.

Mathilde's slow rotation -- it makes only about one revolution in 17 days at "roughly the velocity of an overweight ant," according to Yeomans -- has researchers puzzled, and the NEAR images may help resolve that mystery.

Discovered in 1885 in Vienna and named for the wife of the vice director of the Paris observatory, Mathilde is a C-type asteroid, one of the most common types of asteroids and also one of the most primitive.
Astronomers believe Mathilde and other asteroids could be the material left over from the formation of the planets, including Earth, around 4.6 billion years ago.

But the flyby of Mathilde was not part of NEAR's main mission; the rock just happened to be on the way to Eros, another, slightly smaller asteroid that NEAR will encounter in early 1999 and spend a year examining.

To get there, the solar-powered NEAR will get a boost from Earth's gravitational pull in a "slingshot" pass around our planet. NEAR will orbit the potato-shaped Eros as close as nine miles (14 km) from its surface.
